subject: A suspected terrorist is caught in Dubuque, Iowa...It is our exclusive tonight on the CBS EVENING NEWS WITH KATIE COURIC.

QUOTE OF THE DAY"All animals are equal but some 
      animals are more equal than others." - George Orwell 

DID YOU KNOW?The bloodhound is the only animal whose 
      evidence is admissible in an American court. 

TONIGHT ON THE CBS EVENING NEWSHere is 
      an early preview of what Awe are planning for tonight's CBS EVENING NEWS 
      from Anchor and Managing Editor, Katie Couric... Hi 
      everyone, Late breaking news on Capitol Hill tonight as Congress 
      prepares to send President Bush legislation that would call for the 
      withdrawal of troops to start this October. After days of harsh words 
      between the administration and the Democratic leadership about the vote, 
      the White House remains steadfast about President Bush's plans to veto 
      this legislation. Sharyl Attkisson will report. David 
      Martin will give a Reality Check on the state of the troop surge in 
      Iraq, how it's working and where funds are needed most on the ground 
      there. Next, Bob Orr will have an update on a story he 
      broke for CBS News about the case of a man who calls himself "The Bishop." 
      This morning, federal authorities arrested a man suspected of sending 
      threatening letters and two dud pipe bombs. We'll have more details on the 
      case and the arrest. When John McCain started campaigning months 
      ago for the Republican nomination, he was the presumed front-runner. Now 
      that he has trailed Rudy Giuliani and Mitt Romney in polls, he's 
      attempting to breathe life into his campaign. Today, McCain formally 
      declared his candidacy, and Jim Axelrod will have the full story. 
      Residents of Eagle Pass, Texas, say they can't remember the last 
      time a tornado struck their area. But the one that came to town yesterday 
      was a monster - destroying two schools, killing seven people and damaging 
      more than 20 homes. Elsewhere, flooding and high winds took their toll. 
      Hari Sreenivasan will survey the damage. Ask a kid their 
      favorite food, and you're likely to hear chips, cookies or other sugar- or 
      fat-loaded snacks. What happens when a school reforms the way kids eat? 
      Nancy Cordes will show you. Finally, we'll tell you about 
      what could be a planet a lot like Earth. It seems to be roughly the same 
      temperature and size, and may even have water. The hitch: it is 120 
      trillion miles away. Sandra Hughes will have more. I 
      hope you'll join us. Katie For more information 
      on these stories, please click on the following links: Feds 
      Arrest Mail Bombing Suspect Click Here Border Storm Kills 8 
      In U.S., 3 In Mexico Click Here And here's a look at 
      one of the stories we're working on for Thursday's broadcast:
First, it was tainted PET food... Now, there are new concerns 
      about the food WE eat. The China connection. That story and much more, 
      Thursday, on the CBS Evening News. 
      If you would like more information on any of these stories or the 
      broadcast, please click on the following address and e-mail us: 
      evening@cbsnews.com 

TONIGHT ON DAVID 
      LETTERMANJoin Dave tonight on The Late 
      Show with actor Nicolas Cage AND director 
      Barry Sonnenfeld... Plus, musical guests The Fratellis!

THURSDAY
MORNING ON THE EARLY SHOWHarry Smith, Hannah Storm, Julie 
      Chen and Tracy Smith anchor THE EARLY 
      SHOW from New York. Dave Price will 
      bring us the weather. Russ Mitchell is off. Along with 
      the top news of the day, we will also have the following stories:
A NEW TREND IN JOB HUNTING: Applying for a job via video? 
      It may not be as crazy as it sounds. Video resumes are a relatively new 
      tool, but recent surveys found that a surprisingly high number of managers 
      would consider viewing them if an applicant did submit one. Video resumes 
      could be of great value in an increasingly competitive working world. CBS 
      News Science and Technology Correspondent Daniel Sieberg will join 
      us with the latest. PREVENTING INJURY: SUMMER SAFETY FOR YOUR 
      KIDS: Summer is right around the corner and as the temperature rises, 
      so do the risks of serious injury to your kids. EARLY 
      SHOW Consumer Correspondent Susan 
      Koeppen will join us Thursday morning with a warning about common 
      summer hazards for children--beginning in your own back yard. 
      PUPPY'S FIRST STEPS: THE KEY TO A WELL BEHAVED PET: A furry 
      friend is a welcome addition to any family. But a new puppy can challenge 
      even the most seasoned parents. So how can you make sure your puppy stays 
      on the right track? A whole-dog approach from one of the world's best 
      veterinary schools, Puppy's First Steps is a guide on how to raise 
      a well-behaved happy and healthy puppy. Animal behaviorist Dr. Nicholas 
      Dodman will join us Thursday morning with advice for every puppy owner. 
      MY GENERATION: MEDDLING MOMS: Ever since there's been 
      moms...there's been meddling! And no matter how old you get, or how wise 
      you think you are, a mom is always a mom. And as relationship writer Amy 
      Kean tells us, most moms think they know best! Kean will join us Thursday 
      morning with advice on how you can limit the meddling and finally get 
      along. YOUNG AT HEART: NEVER GET SICK: Everyone knows that 
      good health is dependent on a healthy lifestyle - proper diet, exercise 
      and no smoking. But according to a new article in the current issue of 
      AARP The Magazine, some other simple lifestyle changes can prevent 
      illness and keep the doctor away. Steve Slon, the editor or AARP 
      Magazine, will join us Thursday morning with tips you won't want to 
      miss. CSI SNEAK PEEK: Thursday night's episode of 
      CSI features a washed-up boxer who gets fished out of a swimming 
      pool. In an exclusive preview scene you won't see anywhere else, Grissom 
      and Sara get the scoop from a local cop at the crime scene... a 
      mom-and-pop brothel just outside of Sin City. Thursday morning, we'll take 
      a sneak peek at the action. WEDDING IN A WEEK: FOOD, DRINK AND 
      CAKE TASTING: As the big day approaches in our Wedding in a 
      Week series, master party planner Colin Cowie, and author of 
      the new book Extraordinary Weddings, joins us along with Chef Katy 
      Sparks from Great performance for Hudson to give our lucky couple Lisa 
      Mayo and Stephen Wilfong a tasting of their Wedding Menu. If you 
      would like more information on any of these stories or the broadcast, 
      please click on the following address and e-mail us: earlyshow@cbs.com
